sentences.sentence: I dreamed that I was sitting on the ground outside of my wall, and that I saw a man come down from a great black cloud.
He was as bright as a flame, so that I could hardly bear to look towards him.
His expression was most terrifying( 令人恐惧的 ), impossible for words to describe.
When he stepped upon the ground with his feet, I thought the earth trembled( 摇晃 ), and all the air looked as if it had been filled with flashes of fire.
He moved forward towards me, with a long spear( 矛 ) in his hand.
When he came closer, he spoke to me: “Seeing all these things have not brought you to ask for forgiveness, now you shall die!”
At these words I thought he lifted up the spear( 矛 ) that was in his hand to kill me.
I cannot describe the horrors( 恐惧 ) of my soul at this terrible vision( 景象 ).
Nor can I describe the impression that remained upon my mind when I awoke and found it was just a dream!
In the past, I had never had much thought of God, or that I was being punished for my sin( 罪过 ).
I only said to myself often, that I was an unfortunate dog, and born to always suffer.
It is true, when I first got on shore here, and found all my ship’s crew drowned( 淹死的 ), and myself spared, I was surprised with a kind of heavenly joy.
If I had thought that God had helped me, this joy might have turned into true thankfulness.
Instead I was merely glad I was alive, without the least reflection upon the goodness of the God who had preserved me.
The growing up of the corn had at first some little influence upon me, as long as I thought it had something miraculous( 奇迹般的 ) in it.
But as soon as that miraculous( 奇迹般的 ) part of the thought was removed, all the impression that it made on me went away also.
But now, when I began to be sick, my conscience( 良心 ) at last began to awaken, and I began to feel shame at my past life.
The good advice of my father came to my mind.
I presently remembered what my father had said: that if I did go to sea, God would not bless me.
“Now,” I said, “what my father said has happened: God’s justice has come for me, and I have none to help or hear me.
I rejected God’s gift, which had given me a life in which I might have been happy and easy.
Now I have difficulties to struggle with, and no help, no comfort, no advice.
Lord, be my help, for I am in great difficulty!”
This was the first prayer that I had made for many years.
But to return to my journal( 日记 ).
June 28.—Having been somewhat refreshed( 恢复精神的 ) with the sleep I had had, I considered that now was my time to look after myself in my illness.
The first thing I did was to fill a large bottle with water, and set it upon my table in reach of my bed.
Then I got a piece of goat’s flesh and cooked it on the coals, but could eat very little.
After I had eaten, I tried to walk, but found myself still very weak, so I went only a little way.
I sat down upon the ground, looking out upon the sea, which was very calm and smooth.
As I sat here, some such thoughts as these occurred to me:—
Where do the earth and sea come from?
And where do I, and all the other creatures, come from?
Then it followed most naturally:—it is God that has made it all.
But then, if God has made all these things, He guides and rules them all.
If so, nothing can happen without His knowledge.
And if nothing happens without His knowledge, He knows that I am here, and am in this awful situation.
And if nothing happens without His planning, He has planned for all this to happen to me.
Immediately it followed:—
Why has God done this to me?
What have I done, that I should suffer like this?

My conscience( 良心 ) presently stopped me in that line of questioning( 质疑 ), and seemed as if it spoke to me like a voice: “You look back upon a wasted life, and ask what you have done to deserve this?”
These thoughts disturbed( 烦扰 ) me very much.
I walked back to my shelter( 住所 ) as if I were going to bed, but I had no desire to sleep.
Now I remembered that the Brazilians( 巴西人 ) use nothing but tobacco when they are ill, and I had a roll of tobacco in one of my boxes.
I went, directed by Heaven, no doubt; for in this box I found a cure both for soul and body.
I found the tobacco, and took out one of the Bibles( 圣经 ) as well.
I soaked( 浸湿 ) the tobacco for an hour or two in some wine, and then drank it when I lay down.
While the tobacco was being prepared, I took up the Bible( 圣经 ), and began to read.
Having opened the book at random( 随意地 ), the first words that appeared to me were these: “Call on me in the day of trouble, and I will save you; and you shall praise me.”
These words were very fitting to my situation, and made some impression upon my thoughts at the time of reading them.
It was getting late, and I wanted to sleep.
But before I lay down, I did what I never had done in all my life.
I kneeled( 跪下 ) down, and prayed to God to save me.
After my broken and imperfect prayer was over, I drank the wine.
I then lay down and quickly fell into a sound sleep, and did not wake until around three o’clock in the afternoon of the next day.
When I awoke I found myself very refreshed( 精神抖擞的 ), and my spirits were lively and cheerful.
In short, I felt no sickness the next day, but felt much better. This was the 29th.
The 30th I went out with my gun, but did not care to travel too far.
I was a little sick the next day, which was the 1st of July, but it was not much.
July 2.—I made some more medicine, and doubled the quantity which I drank.
July 3.—I finally got over( 从...中恢复过来 ) my illness for good, although I did not recover my full strength for some weeks after.
While I was thus gathering strength, my thoughts ran repeatedly upon these words from the Bible( 圣经 ), “I will save you”.
I was worried that I would never be saved from this island—but then I realized that God had saved me already, from my illness, and I had not thanked Him.
How could I then expect Him to save me again?
This thought touched my heart, and I immediately kneeled( 跪下 ) down and thanked God aloud, for my recovery from my sickness.
July 4.—In the morning I took the Bible( 圣经 ) and began to read it, starting with the New Testament( 新约 ).
I decided to read a while every morning and every night.
It was not long until I found my heart more deeply and sincerely( 由衷地 ) touched by the wickedness( 堕落 ) of my past life.
The impression of my dream returned, and the words, “All these things have not brought you to seek forgiveness,” ran again and again through my thoughts.
I was seriously asking God to give me forgiveness, when it happened that reading the Bible( 圣经 ), I found these words:
“He is a Prince( 君主 ) and a Savior( 救世主 ) to give forgiveness, and to give mercy( 仁慈 ).”
I threw down the book, and with my heart as well as my hands lifted up to heaven, and in joy I cried out aloud, “Jesus( 耶稣 ), Prince( 君主 ) and Savior( 救世主 ), give me forgiveness!”
This was the first time I could say, in the true sense of the word, that I prayed in all my life.
Now I prayed, truly understanding who and what I was, and trusting in God’s words.
From this time, I may say, I began to hope that God would hear me.
While my daily life remained unchanged, my mind began to accept it much better.
I had a great deal of comfort within, a feeling which I had known nothing of before.
Also, my health and strength returned.
I spent the 4th of July to the 14th walking about with my gun in my hand, gathering up my strength after my sickness.
One thing I learned from this sickness was that being outside in the rainy season was the most dangerous thing to my health.

question.cn: 为什么Robinson生病的时候要吃烟草？
question.en: Why did Robinson eat the tobacco when he was ill?

options.en: Because the God told him to do so.
Because he had nothing to eat.

options.cn: 因为他记得巴西人生病的时候通过吃烟草来治疗。
options.en: Because he remembered that the Brazilians eat tobacco to cure diseases.

analysis: 文中说：“Now I remembered that the Brazilians use nothing but tobacco when they are ill, and I had a roll of tobacco in one of my boxes.”所以选C。

question.cn: Robinson生病的时候读的什么书？
question.en: What book did Robinson read while he was ill?

analysis: 文中说：“While the tobacco was being prepared, I took up the Bible, and began to read.”所以选C。

question.en: What did Robinson do before he slept?

options.en: He knelt down and prayed to God.
He took a walk on the sand.
He ate a large piece of meat.

analysis: 文中说：“But before I lay down, I did what I never had done in all my life. I knelt down, and prayed to God to save me.”所以选A。
